channel.title: My Current Project - Need some Opinions
channel.description:
Well, with me being in school, I've been thinking a lot about Math (Seeing how I'm the best at Algebra 1 in my class), and an idea hit me. I could make a program that will solve all sorts of algebra problems, along with showing the work. Here's where you guys come in.
Oh, and if you don't support this program or have anything negative to say about it or me, then just gtfo.
I probably wouldn't be using this, because it'd be faster just to do it in my head. But, it's something to do and C++/DirectX is getting on my nerves right now.
Anyways, I need suggestions on what would make it look best. It'll be supporting variables, using the Order of Operations, etc... But, to make it most user-friendly and best-looking, I don't know. Something I want to avoid is a plain text box and a result. I'm looking for something that maybe has tabs, and makes the math problem flexible.
Thanks,
~Lin

item.title: My Current Project - Need some Opinions
item.dc:creator: @b_b0yz_4 b b0yz 4
item.description:
@b_b0yz_4 wrote:

Hey Guys! I am in the eigth grade and I love math. I am currently in Algebra (Could of been in Algebra 1 if I got an A, but I had to get a B+) and I was wondering how you guys make programs for your TI-84s. Also Lin Like you are in your class I am the best in mine, and I think this program will be great. If you can get this to work I can show it to all the retards in my grade and they will finaly learn. Soo keep up the good work and can’t waite for it to be finished.

Read full topic
item.source: My Current Project - Need some Opinions

item.title: My Current Project - Need some Opinions
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:10, topic:296254”][quote author=Newty link=topic=392279.msg2920651#msg2920651 date=1250725987]
When I was a Junior, last year, I wrote a program using the TI-84 (I think) that did stuff like area/peremiter/volume/py theroem/and another one I can’t seem to remember, althogh I should. It took input from the user, and it was an amazing tool to use during tests

So yeah, I would suggest using an advanced calculator, so you can “cheat” without your teacher knowing.
[/quote]

Lool, when I was in geometry last year, I was writing a lot of TI-83 programs too. I made a program that would reduce radicals to their lowest forms, it was hawt. Then I had a bunch of other Geometrical and Trigonometrical programs to help me out on tests and stuff.[/quote]

They really do come in handy on exams, tests, etc.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:6, topic:296254”]Alright, here’s a little screenshot of the progress (I just started it as I posted the topic)… Too bad I didn’t really get any suggestions

Currently, all of the buttons work, and the lists update properly. I still have to allow variable using, add in Order of Operations (yuck), and then solving, before it becomes of any use.[/quote]

Budda and I both suggested something…

item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Alright, here’s a little screenshot of the progress (I just started it as I posted the topic)… Too bad I didn’t really get any suggestions

Currently, all of the buttons work, and the lists update properly. I still have to allow variable using, add in Order of Operations (yuck), and then solving, before it becomes of any use.

It took input from the user, and it was an amazing tool to use during tests

So yeah, I would suggest using an advanced calculator, so you can “cheat” without your teacher knowing.[/quote]

This.
Get a graphics calculator, and make ‘programs’ in them. They normally have an actual menu and shit so you make them on the calculator, then run them.

item.title: My Current Project - Need some Opinions
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

When I was a Junior, last year, I wrote a program using the TI-84 (I think) that did stuff like area/peremiter/volume/py theroem/and another one I can’t seem to remember, althogh I should. It took input from the user, and it was an amazing tool to use during tests

So yeah, I would suggest using an advanced calculator, so you can “cheat” without your teacher knowing.
